thread.title: North Augusta looks to buy land at Riverside Village, but it's raising environmental concerns - NewsBreak
thread.title_full: North Augusta looks to buy land at Riverside Village, but it's raising environmental concerns - NewsBreak

author: Shawn Cabbagestalk
title: North Augusta looks to buy land at Riverside Village, but it's raising environmental concerns - NewsBreak
text:
By Shawn Cabbagestalk ,
2 hours ago
NORTH AUGUSTA, S.C. (WJBF) – North Augusta is looking to buy land at Riverside Village to build a cyber office hub using state settlement money.
The city is negotiating to buy one of the last open sites in Riverside Village for a new cyber facility, but the site’s proximity to Brick Pond Park is raising environmental concerns.
“If you look Brick Pond Park a couple of years ago had nice wetlands around it and lots of develop, now it’s all apartment complexes,” said Tonya Bonitatibus, executive director of Savannah Riverkeeper.
The property sits just west of the Center Street roundabout. Engineers say the site could support an 80-thousand-square-foot building.
The city would own it and lease to cyber tenants.
“I think, the last big chunk of remaining land that doesn’t have a building on it around around the ponds,” Bonitatibus said.
Savannah Riverkeeper Tonya Bonitatibus says the site isn’t just another open lot, it’s the last buffer protecting Brick Pond Park’s stormwater system.
“You can’t turn the whole thing into concrete. You have to have room for your storm water retain on site and not just be rushed directly into the pond,” she said.
The group says the city needs a clear plan for managing stormwater as development tightens the space that once held and filtered the rain.
“How are they gonna get rid of that storm water if the space that used to hold the rainwater is now all buildings? I think the quick answer to that is increased flooding,” Bonitatibus said.
The plan replaces earlier proposals for townhomes and retail and moves Riverside Village closer to full build-out.
“I think there’s probably a pretty expansive review that needs to happen what is North Augusta doing to its riverfront in that community? And is that really what the taxpayers want,” Bonitatibus asked.
The next few months will bring more negotiations, planning commission decisions, and a formal Council vote.
